habitat_description:
The western fence lizard is a common species in the western United States,
ranging from Washington south to Baja California and east through the Great
Basin to western Utah (Bell and Price 1996; Stebbins 2003). In the SWReGAP
region it occurs in the western quarter of Utah and all of Nevada except the
southern tip ( Linsdale 1940; Rawley 1970; Stebbins 2003).
Occupies a variety of environments (Stebbins 2003), including (1) disturbed
areas, roadsides, gravel beds, or rock quarries; (2) rocky areas with boulders,
cliffs, canyons, outcrops, talus slopes, or lava flows; (3) shrublands such as
chaparral, sagebrush, creosote, saltbush, mixed oak-grasslands, or shrubsteppe;
(4) riparian areas (such as with Populus fremontii, Fraxinus velutina, and
tamarisk invaded), stream beds/banks, or cobble bars adjacent to rivers; and (5)
coniferous woodlands (mostly pinyon-juniper) and open montane coniferous
forests (Pinus jeffreyi, P. ponderosa, or Pseudotsuga menziesii) (Linsdale 1940;
Johnson 1965; Clark 1973; Goldberg 1974; Tanner 1975; Jameson and Allison
1976; Whitaker and Maser 1981; Cole 1983; Adolph 1990; Sinervo and Losos
1991; Morrison et al. 1994; Grover 1996; Morrison and Hall 1999; Zani 2001;
Sabo and Power 2002).

This species is almost always found on exposed rocks if present and is largely
restricted to rocky environments, especially in Utah and Nevada ( Linsdale 1940;
Smith 1946; Clark 1973). Will also use large trees in open forests and riparian
areas but usually avoids open grasslands or dense shrubs unless boulders or
fence present (Fitch 1940; Davis and Verbeek 1972; Grover 1996). Seems to
prefer exposed sites but with shade and shelter nearby; burrows in soil or under
logs or rocks to nest, to escape heat in summer, and to hibernate in winter
(Fitch 1940; Smith 1946; Gray and Stroud 1980; Sinervo and Losos 1991).
Often found on fences, wood or rock piles, downed logs, tree stumps,
trunks/limbs of trees, or buildings because it uses its climbing skills to take
advantage of rough, inclined surfaces (Smith 1946; Davis and Verbeek 1972;
Sinervo and Losos 1991; Morrison and Hall 1999).

Range-wide elevation limits are from sea level to 3300 m ( Bell and Price 1996;
Stebbins 2003).
